channel.title: NYT > Education
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ohio State Professor Luke Perez Put on Leave After Tackling Filmmaker Over Epstein
item.description: After another journalist interviewed the university’s former president about Jeffrey Epstein, a professor physically intervened when a documentarian wanted to ask more questions.
item.dc:creator: Alan Blinder
item.media:credit: Andrew Spear for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Ohio State University campus in Columbus, Ohio. A prominent donor to the school was connected to Jeffrey Epstein. An altercation happened after the former president was asked about those ties.

item.title: Ontario Lifts Tuition Freeze at Public Universities
item.description: The move will allow the schools to raise tuition for the first time since 2019 as part of a broader plan to boost funding for higher education in the Canadian province.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Wa Lone/Reuters
item.media:description: Students at the St. George Campus of the University of Toronto, Canada, last year.

item.title: Immigration Judge Says Rumeysa Ozturk, a Tufts Student, Cannot Be Deported
item.description: The student, Rumeysa Ozturk, who is from Turkey, was detained by immigration agents last year after she co-wrote a pro-Palestinian opinion article for her student newspaper.
item.dc:creator: Jonah E. Bromwich
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rumeysa Ozturk was held in detention in Louisiana for 45 days until a federal judge released her on bail.

item.title: Gabor Boritt, Refugee Who Became Expert on Lincoln, Dies at 86
item.description: He survived the Holocaust and Communist rule in Hungary, arrived penniless in New York and made himself into a pre-eminent Civil War scholar.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.category: Gilder Lehrman Institute of American History
item.media:credit: Jake Boritt, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Gabor Boritt in 2006. At Gettysburg College in Pennsylvania, near the site of the 1863 battle that changed the course of the Civil War, he built a career around Abraham Lincoln.

item.title: Epstein Used Cash to Wield His Influence at Columbia and N.Y.U.
item.description: Federal records show that Jeffrey Epstein used donations and connections as he sought to gain college admission for young women in his orbit.
item.dc:creator: Sharon Otterman
item.media:credit: House Oversight Democrats
item.media:description: Jeffrey Epstein continued to have access to college administrators even after his felony convictions and prison sentence for solicitation of prostitution by a minor.

item.title: Starting at Harvard and Falling for Your First Tree
item.description: A freshman seminar encourages students to behave differently in the world and feel more passionately about biodiversity.
item.dc:creator: Margaret Roach and Sophie Park
item.media:description: Each Harvard University freshman in the “Tree” seminar must choose a single tree among 16,000 at the Arnold Arboretum as their study partner for the semester. For Stella Rosa Guest, it was a red-leaved Japanese maple.

item.title: San Francisco Teachers Begin Strike, Closing School for 50,000 Students
item.description: The strike closed public schools for more than 50,000 students in the city and had no end date. Health care costs are a key issue in negotiations.
item.dc:creator: Soumya Karlamangla, Laurel Rosenhall and Shawn Hubler
item.media:credit: Stephen Lam/Reuters
item.media:description: San Francisco teachers went on strike Monday for the first time since 1979. The walkout has no end date.

item.title: New Email Shows Bard President Leon Botstein Thanked Epstein for Caribbean Trip
item.description: Leon Botstein, Bard’s president, also invited Jeffrey Epstein to visit a high school linked to Bard College and sent him well wishes after stories were published about his sexual abuse of minors.
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel
item.media:credit: Arden Wray for The New York Times
item.media:description: Leon Botstein has led Bard College since 1975.

item.title: Smaller N.Y.C. Classes Will Cost Millions. Can Mamdani Pull It Off?
item.description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani wants to make classes smaller across the largest U.S. school system. Like other parts of his agenda, it’s a costly task.
item.dc:creator: Troy Closson
item.media:credit: Elizabeth D. Herman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A state law requires New York City to decrease public school class sizes to 25 students or less by 2028.

item.title: Bard College President Leon Botstein Was Close With Jeffrey Epstein
item.description: Bard College’s president, Leon Botstein, said his school needed cash. But a rare watch and a Caribbean visit show how his relationship with Jeffrey Epstein sometimes veered into the personal.
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel
item.media:credit: Arden Wray for The New York Times
item.media:description: Leon Botstein has been leading Bard College since 1975. He says his connections with Jeffrey Epstein were focused on raising money for the school.

item.title: Hegseth Says Defense Department Will Cut Ties With Harvard
item.description: Mr. Hegseth’s order appeared to target his alma mater, Harvard’s Kennedy School for public policy.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.category: Kennedy, John F, School of Government
Belfer Center for Science and International Affairs
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Harvard Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University.

item.title: Harvard Proposes Capping As at 20 Percent to Curb Grade Inflation
item.description: A recent report found that a majority of grades given out at Harvard were A’s. Professors will vote on a proposal to limit the number to around 20 percent.
item.dc:creator: Mark Arsenault
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Harvard University campus in Cambridge, Mass.

item.title: 12 Columbia Professors and Students Are Arrested at Anti-ICE Protest
item.description: Demonstrators, who were demanding that the university provide more protection for international students, blocked Broadway.
item.dc:creator: Sharon Otterman and Olivia Bensimon
item.media:credit: Marco Postigo Storel for The New York Times
item.media:description: About 150 protesters called on Columbia to strengthen protections for international students.

item.title: Educators Sue to Keep Immigration Agents From Schools and Bus Stops
item.description: The lawsuit is challenging a Trump administration policy allowing federal agents near locations such as schools, churches and hospitals.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Mervosh
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the security team for the school district in Fridley, Minn., monitored neighborhoods near local schools during dismissal last week amid heightened federal immigration enforcement activity.

item.title: New Research Absolves the Woman Blamed for a Dynasty’s Ruin
item.description: A Chinese king’s infatuation with a woman was seen as the reason that a golden age collapsed. Evidence suggests climate change and internal strife played bigger roles.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Researchers digging to unearth remnants of what is believed to have been a fortified gate guarding an entrance to the capital of the Western Zhou dynasty, near Hejia Village, China, in December.

item.title: Judge Orders U.S. to Facilitate Return of College Student Who Was Deported in Error
item.description: A federal prosecutor said last month that ICE had made a “mistake” in deporting Any Lucia López Belloza, a college freshman in Massachusetts, to Honduras.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Ziegler and Mattathias Schwartz
item.media:credit: Massdeportationdefense.Org, via Reuters
item.media:description: Any Lucia López Belloza, a Massachusetts college student, was mistakenly deported in November to Honduras.

item.title: Jury Deadlocked in Trial of Pro-Palestinian Demonstrators at Stanford
item.description: A judge declared a mistrial after a jury could not reach a verdict in a case in which five current and former students were charged with felonies.
item.dc:creator: Soumya Karlamangla
item.media:credit: Stephen Lam/San Francisco Chronicle, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Students walked by a tent encampment in White Plaza at Stanford in 2024.

item.title: Measles Outbreak Hits Ave Maria University in Florida
item.description: More than 40 people have fallen ill at Ave Maria University, raising fears that college campuses may soon experience more measles outbreaks.
item.dc:creator: Teddy Rosenbluth
item.media:credit: Zack Wittman for The New York Times

item.title: 2 Dead, One Wounded in Shooting at South Carolina State University
item.description: The violence on Thursday night took place in a residence hall near the site of two other shootings in October.
item.dc:creator: Chris Hippensteel
item.media:credit: WLTX, via Associated Press
item.media:description: This image made from a video shows the South Carolina State University campus in Orangeburg, S.C., after a shooting Thursday night.

item.title: Texas University Closes Exhibition With Anti-ICE Artwork
item.description: The exhibition at the University of North Texas by a Mexican-born artist included the language “Immigration and Cruelty Enforcement.”
item.dc:creator: Michaela Towfighi

item.title: One Last Chat With David Brooks
item.description: Before leaving The Times after 22 years, David Brooks responds to readers’ questions.
item.dc:creator: New York Times Opinion
item.media:credit: Grade Solomon

item.title: Justice Department Sues Harvard for Admissions Records
item.description: The Trump administration appears to have renewed its pressure campaign against Harvard since President Trump backtracked this month on a possible settlement with the Ivy League school.
item.dc:creator: Michael C. Bender and Alan Blinder
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: The lawsuit is the second government action targeting Harvard in the two weeks since President Trump’s sudden reversal of his position on a potential deal to end the administration’s pressure campaign on the university.

item.title: San Francisco Teachers End Strike After 4 Days
item.description: Public schools are expected to reopen on Wednesday for 50,000 students in the city. Teachers demanded higher wages and health care benefits.
item.dc:creator: Soumya Karlamangla
item.media:credit: Carlos Barria/Reuters
item.media:description: San Francisco teachers went on strike this week for the first time since 1979 in pursuit of higher wages and health care benefits.

item.title: Manhattan Has Its Own Historian
item.description: Harold Holzer, an expert on Abraham Lincoln, is taking over the role of borough historian. He is looking ahead to some significant milestones this year.
item.dc:creator: James Barron
item.category: Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art
Roosevelt House Public Policy Institute (Hunter College)
item.media:credit: Jackie Molloy for The New York Times
item.media:description: Harold Holzer in the Manhattan borough president’s map office.

item.title: ICE Is Detaining Hundreds of Children
item.description: The number of children in immigration detention has spiked since last year. Families describe poor conditions and little education.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan, Sarah Mervosh and Allison McCann
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times

item.title: Milan Has an Affordable Housing Crisis. Can the Olympic Village Help?
item.description: The accommodation for athletes includes a video game lounge, massage room and a range of food options. Starting from September, it will house students — or at least those who can afford the rent.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:credit: Vincent Alban/The New York Times
item.media:description: The Olympic Village complex in Milan. The village’s developer has touted it as a great gift to the city that will provide 6 percent of the beds needed for students.
